title: Problem Statement
content: Erdős Problem #72 asks: Does there exist a set A ⊂ ℕ of density 0 and a constant c > 0 such that every sufficiently large graph with average degree ≥ c contains a cycle whose length is in A? The answer is YES, proved by Verstraëte (2005) non-constructively and by Liu-Montgomery (2020) for powers of 2.

title: Counting Function
content: The counting function |A ∩ [0,n]| counts how many elements of A appear up to n. This is the foundation for defining density. For powers of 2, this is approximately log₂(n), while for arithmetic progressions it grows linearly.

title: Density Zero
content: A set A has density 0 if |A ∩ [1,n]|/n → 0 as n → ∞. Examples: powers of 2 (log n / n → 0), perfect squares (√n / n → 0). Non-examples: arithmetic progressions (constant density 1/d), primes (~n/ln(n) / n → 0, but too slowly for this problem).

title: Powers of Two
content: The set {1, 2, 4, 8, 16, ...} = {2^k : k ∈ ℕ}. Erdős believed this set would NOT work as an unavoidable cycle length set. Liu and Montgomery (2020) proved him wrong! Only O(log n) powers of 2 exist up to n, making this a very sparse set.

title: Average Degree
content: The average degree of a graph is (Σ deg(v)) / |V|, which equals 2|E|/|V|. Dense graphs have high average degree. The key question: how high must average degree be to guarantee specific cycle lengths?

title: Cycle Lengths in a Graph
content: The set of all k such that G contains a cycle of length k. For example, K₄ has cycles of lengths 3 and 4. The question asks: which cycle lengths must appear in all sufficiently dense graphs?

title: Unavoidable Cycle Lengths
content: A set A is unavoidable with threshold c if every large graph with average degree ≥ c contains some cycle whose length is in A. The key insight: high density forces rich structure, and some cycle length from A must appear. A is strongly unavoidable if some threshold c works.

title: Erdős Problem #72 Statement
content: The formal statement: ∃ A ⊂ ℕ with density 0, ∃ c > 0, such that every large graph with average degree ≥ c has a cycle of length in A. This combines number-theoretic sparsity (density 0) with extremal graph theory (cycle forcing).

title: Bollobás (1977)
content: If A is an infinite arithmetic progression containing even numbers, then A is strongly unavoidable. Example: A = {2, 4, 6, 8, ...} works. But arithmetic progressions have positive density, so this doesn't solve Problem #72 directly. It shows the cycle-forcing phenomenon exists.

title: Verstraëte (2005)
content: Non-constructive existence proof: SOME density-0 set A exists that is strongly unavoidable. This solved Problem #72 in principle, but didn't identify which sets work. The proof uses probabilistic and compactness arguments.

title: Liu-Montgomery (2020)
content: BREAKTHROUGH: Powers of 2 are strongly unavoidable! There exists c > 0 such that every large graph with average degree ≥ c has a cycle whose length is a power of 2. This was surprising because Erdős was 'almost certain' this would fail.

title: Main Theorem
content: Combining Liu-Montgomery (powers of 2 are unavoidable) with the fact that powers of 2 have density 0, we get the complete solution to Erdős Problem #72. The $100 prize was awarded.

title: Erdős Was Wrong
content: Erdős stated he was 'almost certain' that powers of 2 would NOT work. He expected the required average degree would need to grow with graph size. Liu-Montgomery proved a CONSTANT threshold suffices. This is a rare instance of Erdős's intuition being definitively wrong.

title: Open Question: Perfect Squares
content: Perfect squares {1, 4, 9, 16, 25, ...} have density 0 (only √n up to n). But it's UNKNOWN whether they are strongly unavoidable. This remains an open question in extremal combinatorics.

title: Optimal Threshold
content: For a given unavoidable set A, what is the smallest c that works? Liu-Montgomery gives some explicit (but large) bound for powers of 2. Finding the optimal threshold remains open. It's likely much smaller than the current best bound.

title: General Liu-Montgomery
content: Liu-Montgomery actually proved a more general result: any set A with logarithmic growth and containing only even numbers (plus possibly 1) is strongly unavoidable. Powers of 2 is just a special case of this general theorem.
